awd_titl_txt: 2D Grain Boundary Phases: Establishing an Electronic Basis for Engineering Superior  Copper Alloy Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical summary: 
Metals and alloys (blends) such as bronze have been used by mankind for millennia before the atomic nature of matter was known. Even today, the details of how atoms interact are known only for a few combinations of metals, because the tools for studying materials at the atomic level have only recently become available. Those details have become increasingly important as modern technological advances demand smaller, lighter, and more compact designs with increased capabilities. This project will explore why adding certain metals make copper more flexible while others make it more brittle, (or more/less strong, or more/less conductive). The origin of this behavior can be traced to the interaction of the atoms and their electrons at internal defects called grain boundaries, where the atoms are packed together imperfectly. These boundaries are found throughout all metals, and greatly impact the behavior of metal parts, from wires in computer chips to seat brackets in airplanes. Understanding these interactions will allow engineers to design alloys from the atom level upward for the first time, enabling them to tailor properties of the alloys to reduce the power used in manufacturing, to prolong the service life of metal parts, or to create complex designs without compromising performance. The results of this work will be shared with the scientific and industrial communities at national and international technical conferences by students who, when they graduate, will become highly educated and practically trained members of the workforce. Participating in this project will also expose students to outreach and mentoring opportunities through several existing programs at SUNY Poly, including the continuing education of secondary school teachers, summer science camps for high school students, and a general science seminar series at a local branch of the public library. The professor and her team are committed to these efforts to de-mystify technology and make science (and scientists) accessible to all. 


Technical summary: 
Grain boundaries strongly impact a range of properties and behavior of polycrystalline metals; in nanostructured materials this effect can be even more dramatic because the number of atoms participating in those boundaries constitutes an appreciable fraction of the total atoms in the sample. As a result, observable properties are often dominated by interface, not bulk, material properties. Solute segregating to some or all of these interfaces can change the energy, mobility, structure and cohesion of boundaries through electronic interactions with the surrounding matrix. The nature of these interactions will be examined using a combination of analytical transmission electron microscopy, electron energy loss spectroscopy, and density functional theory. These results will be used to elucidate the correlations between the atomic and electronic structures at grain boundaries and observed electro-mechanical properties of select copper alloys, to enable future materials-by-design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Metals and alloys (blends) such as bronze have been used by mankind for millennia before the atomic nature of matter was known. Even today, the details of how atoms interact are understood only for a few combinations of metals, because the tools for studying materials at the atomic level have only recently become available. Those details have become increasingly important as modern technological advances demand smaller, lighter, and more compact designs with increased capabilities. This project studied why adding certain metals make copper more flexible while others make it more brittle, (or more/less strong, or more/less conductive). The origin of this behavior can be traced to the interaction of the atoms and their electrons at internal defects called grain boundaries, where the atoms are packed together imperfectly, as shown in the accompanying figure. In this schematic drawing, the copper atoms are blue, and the purple impurities decorate two grain boundaries. Such boundaries are found throughout all metals, and greatly impact the behavior of metal parts, from wires in computer chips to seat brackets in airplanes. By adding minute amounts of other metals into copper and measuring the electrical and mechanical properties of the resulting blend, we studied how the grain boundaries are changed by the impurities we introduced.

The merit of our approach arose from the unprecedented opportunity offered by applying state-of-the-art microscopes to visualize the atomic structure while simultaneously using electron-based spectroscopy to understand the bonding at individual grain boundaries. The interpretation of the results from "clean" and "decorated" grain boundaries has been assisted by physics-based simulations to confirm the fundamental origin of the real behavior we have observed in the laboratory. By establishing the link between macroscopic behavior and inter-atomic bonding, new alloys can be designed for specific applications requiring, for example, improved adhesion or increased hardness.

Our results are being shared with the scientific and industrial communities at national and international technical conferences. To date, this program has resulted in seven academic and industrial seminars by the professor, three by the graduate student involved in the work, and a capstone research poster by an undergraduate intern. When these students graduate, they will be highly educated and practically trained members of the high-tech workforce, immediately employable in any of the many industries that rely on copper and its alloys, from electronics to energy to automotive applications. The importance of the work - and the students' skill sets - extend beyond just copper since the principles developed here and the techniques used to uncover them are broadly applicable to the study and design of other nanostructured metal alloy systems used in additive manufacturing, fuel cells and battery electrodes.

As a result of this project, three undergraduate curriculum modules were developed for flexing and stretching metals, measuring electrical conductivity, and visualizing grain boundaries in metals. These form the basis of an introductory laboratory course for a new degree program in materials science & engineering being developed in our college. In addition to the traditional university students involved in this program, a high school physics teacher was hosted in our laboratory. During her summer internship, she participated in work related to the process development for dilute copper alloy films and their characterization, including the use of state-of-the-art electron microscopes to visualize the structure of the alloys and the distribution of the added metal atoms within the copper. This experience allowed her to develop five age-appropriate curriculum modules to deploy in the high school curriculum, impacting ~70 physics students annually. Finally, educational outreach activities included sessions in a week-long summer "chip camp" for 25 high school students and 25 high school teachers (separate weeks) in each of the first two years of the program, to foster interest in science and de-mystify the technologies that are inside the devices modern life relies on.
